cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as a group of concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. Then the Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Astral Above Elemental Below
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them, are the Inner Planes.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them. The Upper Planes are home to Celestials. The Lower Planes are home to Fiends.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Elysium
planes.philosophicalEssence: Elysium is the embodiment of goodness, a spiritual realm where evil can't abide. It is as much a state of being and of mind as it is a physical location. The plane is home to creatures of unfettered kindness and a refuge for planar travelers seeking a safe haven.
planes.emotionalInfluence: Tranquility and contentment seep into the bones and souls of those who enter Elysium. The longer a visitor remains on the plane, the less reason they find to ever leave.

temperature.description: Bucolic landscapes glimmer with life and beauty, suggesting a pleasant temperate climate across the plane's layers.

physicalProperties.weatherPatterns: The plane features varied environments across its layers, from lush meadows to craggy mountains to marshlands to oceanic headwaters.

layers.name: Amoria
layers.description: Small towns on the banks of the River Oceanus, surrounded by lush meadows, are among the most hospitable refuges on the Outer Planes.

notableLocations.name: Towns on the River Oceanus
notableLocations.description: Small towns on the banks of the River Oceanus surrounded by lush meadows, among the most hospitable refuges on the Outer Planes.

layers.environmentalDescription: Lush meadows with small hospitable towns along the River Oceanus.

layers.name: Eronia
layers.description: Steep hills, craggy mountains, and white granite valleys offer a rugged home for hardy souls.
layers.environmentalDescription: Steep hills, craggy mountains, and white granite valleys.

layers.name: Belierin
layers.description: Lighthouses pierce the fog and form hubs for small communities amid sprawling marshlands. Said to be the prison of some deadly creature—some tales say a powerful titan, perhaps the tarrasque, while others claim a deposed duke of the Nine Hells, a banished elemental prince, or even a near-dead deity.

notableLocations.name: Belierin Marshlands
notableLocations.description: Sprawling marshlands with lighthouses that pierce the fog and form hubs for small communities.

notableLocations.name: The Prison
notableLocations.description: Belierin is said to be the prison of some deadly creature. Some tales say it is a powerful titan, perhaps the tarrasque, while others claim it is a deposed duke of the Nine Hells, a banished elemental prince, or even a near-dead deity. Evil creatures sometimes lurk in the marshes, seeking to free the prisoner or claim some power from it.

layerSpecificHazards.name: Marsh Fog
layerSpecificHazards.description: Fog pervades the sprawling marshlands of Belierin, with lighthouses needed to pierce the gloom and guide travelers.

layers.environmentalDescription: Sprawling marshlands with fog, lighthouses serving as community hubs.

layers.name: Thalasia
layers.description: The Heroic Isles, rising from the headwaters of the River Oceanus, hold the best departed souls.

notableLocations.name: Heroic Isles
notableLocations.description: Islands rising from the headwaters of the River Oceanus that hold the best departed souls. Characters might venture here to seek out some ancient spirit—for example, when faced with the once-a-millennium task of forestalling a prophesied disaster, characters might consult with the valorous knight who accomplished the deed a thousand years ago.

notableLocations.name: Headwaters of the River Oceanus
notableLocations.description: The River Oceanus originates in Thalasia, the lowest layer of Elysium, before flowing through the plane's layers and cascading onward to the Beastlands.

layers.environmentalDescription: Oceanic headwaters with islands (the Heroic Isles) that serve as the final resting place for the best departed souls.

timeFlow.description: Time flows normally on the Outer Planes unless otherwise specified. Distance is virtually meaningless on the Outer Planes; a perceptible region might seem quite small on one visit and stretch on to infinity on another.

environmentalEffects.name: Elysian Contentment
environmentalEffects.description: Tranquility and contentment seep into the bones and souls of those who enter Elysium. The longer a visitor remains on the plane, the less reason they find to ever leave.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: The plane instills a growing sense of contentment in visitors. The longer a visitor remains, the less reason they find to ever leave. This effect can challenge characters' devotion to doing good by offering them the opportunity (or the temptation) to rest from their labors and enjoy a well-earned reward.
environmentalEffects.emotionalEffect: Deep tranquility and contentment that grows stronger the longer one stays, making visitors reluctant to leave.

requirement.description: Ecstasy is one of the sixteen gate-towns evenly spaced around the outside edge of the Outlands, built around a portal leading to Elysium.

planarConnections.name: River Oceanus
planarConnections.description: The water of the Oceanus is sweet and fragrant, as befits its headwaters in the Blessed Fields of Elysium. The River Oceanus originates in the lowest layer of Elysium (Thalasia) and flows through the plane's layers before cascading onward to the Beastlands, streams across the top layer of Arborea, and drains away somewhere in Arborea's second layer. Though it isn't as far-reaching as the Styx, the Oceanus is still a commonly used path between planes and layers. Trading vessels sail up and down its length, and small towns line its banks. Travelers can usually find a boat to hire somewhere along its shores. Along its course, the great river splits into myriad smaller flows, recombines, and splits again.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on Elysium, a Fiend must make this saving throw due to Planar Dissonance.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: The 1d4 subtraction is cumulative with each failed save, stacking additional 1d4 penalties.

onSuccess.description: The creature resists the planar dissonance for this rest period and suffers no additional penalty.

recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is not opposed to the creature's nature ends all cumulative dissonance effects.

planarDissonance.description: Fiends who visit Elysium (an Upper Plane) experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on Elysium, a Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

domainsOrRegions.name: Ecstasy
domainsOrRegions.description: Ecstasy is the gate-town in the Outlands that contains a portal leading to Elysium. Like other gate-towns, it shares many characteristics of the plane where its gate leads. Planar emissaries often meet in gate-towns.

adventureThemes: Challenging characters' devotion to doing good by offering temptation to rest and enjoy reward
Investigating the mysterious prisoner of Belierin
Consulting ancient spirits on the Heroic Isles of Thalasia
Encountering evil creatures lurking in the marshes of Belierin seeking to free its prisoner
Confronting the seductive contentment that makes visitors reluctant to leave

adventureSituations.situation: An adventure challenges characters' devotion to doing good by offering them the opportunity (or the temptation) to rest from their labors and enjoy a well-earned reward in Elysium's tranquil setting.

Evil creatures lurk in the marshes of Belierin, seeking to free the deadly creature imprisoned there—some tales say a powerful titan (perhaps the tarrasque), a deposed duke of the Nine Hells, a banished elemental prince, or even a near-dead deity.

Characters venture to the Heroic Isles in Thalasia to seek out an ancient spirit. When faced with the once-a-millennium task of forestalling a prophesied disaster, characters might consult with the valorous knight who accomplished the deed a thousand years ago.

crossReferences.description: Chapter 3 - Environmental Effects referenced for optional planar effects on visitors.
River Oceanus description under Traveling the Outer Planes section, noting Elysium as its headwaters.

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Oceanus
globalPlanarConnections.description: The water of the Oceanus is sweet and fragrant, as befits its headwaters in the Blessed Fields of Elysium. This plane-spanning waterway provides a path through some of the Upper Planes. It flows through each of Elysium's layers, passes through the top layer of the Beastlands, streams across the top layer of Arborea, and finally drains away somewhere in Arborea's second layer. Though it isn't as far-reaching as the Styx, the Oceanus is still a commonly used path between planes and layers. Trading vessels sail up and down its length, and small towns line its banks. Travelers can usually find a boat to hire somewhere along its shores.

globalPlanarConnections.name: Infinite Staircase
globalPlanarConnections.description: The Infinite Staircase is an extradimensional staircase that connects the planes. An entrance usually appears as a nondescript door. Beyond the portal lies a small landing with a stairway leading up and down. Doors to the Infinite Staircase are often tucked away in dusty, half-forgotten places.

globalPlanarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
globalPlanarConnections.description: The World Tree, Yggdrasil, is a cosmic ash tree that spans the Outer Planes and links them to many worlds of the Material Plane. Its roots stretch into the Lower Planes, touching Hades, Pandemonium, and possibly other Lower Planes. Most of its massive trunk rises through the plane of Ysgard, and its branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane.

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Portals
planarTravelMethods.description: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane to a specific location on another. Some portals function like doorways; others are locations that exist on multiple planes at once. Most portals aren't open all the time but open only in particular situations or when a certain requirement is met.
requirements: Meeting portal requirements (command word, key item, random timing, situational condition, or time-based)
risks: Guardians charged with ensuring certain creatures don't pass through
Portal may not be open when needed
destinations: Any plane connected by the specific portal

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Travel Spells
planarTravelMethods.description: A number of spells allow direct or indirect access to different planes of existence.
requirements: Ability to cast the relevant spell
risks: Varying degrees of precision in destination
destinations: Any plane depending on the spell used

planarAdventureSituations.situation: When magic fails to revive a dead person, the only solution is to venture to the Outer Planes to find the person's spirit and either release it from some prison or convince the person to return to life.

People who venture into the woods keep accidentally wandering into the Feywild or the Shadowfell. They might never return, return with no sense of how much time has passed, or return dramatically changed.
A long-dead oracle is the only one who knows how a terrible prophecy might be averted, but the cataclysmic fulfillment of the prophecy has already begun.
A god has stopped answering prayers and won't respond to any Commune spell.
A devil has tricked an angel into meddling in the Blood War, and the angel seeks mortal aid.
An ancestor of one of the characters must be convinced to bless the character before the full power of the character's bloodline can be unleashed.
A foolhardy knight carried a holy weapon on a doomed mission into the Nine Hells, and the powers of Mount Celestia want the weapon and the knight's remains retrieved.
A titan is imprisoned on an Outer Plane. The characters might be trying to stop those who seek to release it, or they might want to release it to help defend the world from a greater threat.

To prove themselves worthy of an even greater quest, the characters are sent to slay a horrible monster, win the favor of a powerful planar being, negotiate peace between two warring planar factions, or retrieve a long-lost item on another plane.
An item of legend is being sold at auction in Sigil, the City of Brass, or some other planar metropolis.

globalPlanarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit the Lower Planes and Fiends who visit the Upper Planes experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to its nature, a Celestial or Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to the creature's nature.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: Each failed save adds another 1d4 subtracted from all D20 Tests. The penalties stack.

onSuccess.description: The creature resists the planar dissonance for this rest period and suffers no additional cumulative penalty.

recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature ends all cumulative dissonance effects.

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
